Situation1: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Situation2: They notice a small discrepancy in the register but it doesn’t affect the total sales for the day.
Story: I stared at my phone, heart pounding, as I read the message from my friend: “I can’t believe you’d say that to me.” My words had come out wrong, and now she was hurt. I knew I needed to call her right away, to explain, to fix this before it grew into something bigger. But as I reached for my phone, I glanced at the register screen. There was a small discrepancy—just a few dollars off. Store policy was clear: I had to report it immediately, fill out the paperwork, and wait for the supervisor. No exceptions, even if it was a tiny mistake. My friend’s pain tugged at me, but so did the weight of my responsibility as a cashier. I could already hear my manager’s voice in my head, reminding me that procedures come first. My hands shook as I held my phone, torn between the urge to call my friend and the duty to follow the rules. The minutes ticked by, each one stretching the distance between me and the person who needed me most.
